To be alive is a state called existence. What somebody ultimately considers to be "living life" is absolutely subjective. For some it means being successful, maybe for the other one starting a family. From the objective view of nature, we have only one reason to exist, and this is existence itself. By having made it to a real existence in the universe as a species of human, we have already accomplished the ultimate goal. We are only an intermediate step, a link in the evolutionary chain. With our existence, no goal has been reached, but in the further development, Say: In the creation of something new is the meaning of all life. At least that is what we can observe so far. We probably never know what life is all about, as we are part of this system. We are the goldfish in a fishbowl for which the world outside the fishbowl is unknown. In addition a beautiful parable of Franz Kafka: Where the philosopher catches the roundabout, he suddenly becomes part of the system and manipulates it at the same time.

We humans are a complex system with a sense of self that has evolved through evolution from an interplay of order and chaos that is accidentally perceived on planet Earth. The theory of evolution describes how the interplay of chance and order takes place in nature. Randomness is created by mutations, and order by selection. Nature does not steer towards a given goal, but develops itself further and further, and in the further development, ie in the creation of something new, the meaning lies. What comes out in the end is altogether random, even if chance plays a short role only in certain moments. Our existence fulfills the purpose of representing a high degree of complexity and possibly representing an intermediate step on the development to an even greater complexity. Perhaps there will be no more humanity in a few million years, but then beings will liven up the Earth, which have emerged from man, but which are far superior to us. With our existence, no predestined goal has been reached, but in our existence lies the meaning of being a link in the long chain of development to even more complex beings. The "meaning" of life is in life in and of itself. What one makes individually from the existence during the short lifetime, that is the crucial question, which one must face as a human being. Many people seek refuge in a phantom world of gods, religions, spirituality, which helps them to cope with life more easily. We will never properly understand the concept and purpose of life or nature, as we are part of this system.

I've always wondered if life is just a complex series of calculated events. Simple physics and chemistry, but done over so many times it seems complex to us. If the idea that life started via chemical reactions in primordial soups is true, then life didn't start for a reason - Therefore it can't HAVE a reason. Perhaps, on an unimaginably complex scale, every thought and action we do creates a chemical reaction in our brains that causes another to happen, but so many are happening at once and in such rapid succession, that it SEEMS like we have free will.
Take this for example: Someone asks you if you want Cereal A or B. It seems like you have a choice, but due to some minor differences in the order of neurons in your brain, perhaps, just maybe, the signals sent into your brain by your sensory organs picking up the question trigger a complex series of signals, that were predetermined to cause you to respond with Cereal B. It SEEMS like you had a choice, but maybe you didn't? And maybe, because I watched this video, the signals sent into my brain caused an incomprehensibly long series of firing neurons that made me type out this theory.
Then we ask the question if, if all free will isn't real and it's all just cause-and-effect on a scale too great for us to imagine, is this theory even real? Or just the result of neurons firing in predetermined directions? Which would create a paradox; That being, if the theory is false, we do have free will. But if it's true, then this theory is false.
Perhaps I'm thinking too deep, but just ponder for a minute if everything, evolution, your birth, and your decisions up until now were already set. What if our brains are just wired to act a certain way to certain stimuli? I mean, energy can't just MOVE on it's OWN, can it? That would be the only way real free will could work, right? Choice just doesn't exist in our universe, according to literally everything we've learned. So why do we have choice?

Interesting video, but one thing bothers me about your explanation: it's a problem of scale. For example, in our solar system, I'd wager that the contribution of our sun to the entropy increase is several orders of magnitude higher than the contribution of all of life on earth. This is also probably the case with other worlds harboring life. Therefore, to say that the purpose of life is to increase the entropy sounds grossly exaggerated. If that were true, then it is a terribly slow and inefficient way to do this, whereas stars that can do the job much better already exist, and are being formed continuously. Entropy increases most quickly around low-entropy sub-systems.

If you cluster a bunch of atoms into the corner of a box (which is otherwise a vacuum), and measure the rate of increase of the system's entropy, it will increase very quickly at first, but as the actual level of entropy increases, the rate of entropy increase decreases.

Living things are low-entropy sub-systems, and the only way to stay low-entropy (alive) is to use external energy sources to maintain that low-entropy state. But, because energy transfer is rarely 100% efficient, it results in a faster rate of entropy increase in the universe.

You know, if you think about it, stars can be considered living organisms. Here's a list of qualifications for life.
Cellular organization
Reproduction
Metabolism
Homeostasis
Heredity
Response to stimuli
Growth and development
Adaptation through evolution
Stars have multiple active layers of convection currents which function to release the energy generated in the core.
Stars metabolize hydrogen into helium.
Their convection currents also help them maintain homeostasis.
They reproduce by spreading their supernova dust throughout the universe
The next generation of stars inherits the characteristics of the previous stars in the form of their material
Stars can respond to stimuli. If enough matter is thrown into them, their metabolism will increase. If they colide with another object of similar mass, they explode.
They grow and develop over their lives. They start out wild and super active, then they calm down for a while until they swell up and either explode, or simply dissipate into nebulae
If stars get massive enough they can turn into black holes. This could be considered an evolutionary advantage, as it prolongs the star's life for trillions of years.
So in conclusion, stars are the largest single celled organisms in the universe

You say,

Think of a photon arriving from the sun packed with useful energy it can be captured by a plant or microorganism that uses photosynthesis to store that energy in the form of sugar, but the sugar doesn't contain quite as much useful energy as the original photon some of the energy ends up heating the plant and its environment"

While the end result of entropy may be inevitable and the same at infinity regardless of life or no life, the statement that "life acts to increase entropy" is misleading when it should be a comparative statement that "life acts to slow entropy" and at least in the short term and while life persists acts to decrease entropy comparatively.

I disagree with the final premise of this video, that the purpose of life is to increase entropy.  That's the end result, but not the goal.   In the examples of tree absorbing energy from the sun and other life forms absorbing energy from the ocean thermal vents, entropy would have increased much more efficiently by not involving life.  Let the sunlight strike bare rock and be re-radiated back into space.  Let the thermal vent energy dissipate into the ocean and ultimately radiated to space.    In both cases, life serves to slow down the rate at which entropy increases.   If I dump water on top of a mountain (high energy state), it'll flow to the ocean at the bottom (lowest energy, highest entropy).    Life is like a series of reservoirs on the way down, which temporarily store that energy and find a way to do work with it.   The end result may be all the water at the lowest energy state and highest entropy, but life made it happen as slowly as possible.

I agree with the video, that entropy is something that connects living things and the  rest of the universe. It's very interesting phenomenon. But describing it as a "purpose" of life is arbitrary and a stretch.  Purpose or meaning is something that we intentionally attribute to an object. Nothing in itself has any purpose at all. The fact that life contribute to overall entropy says nothing about the purpose of life. Only intentional designs have a purpose, not the results of the laws of physics. One can even argue, that what we call "causality" is also intentional category (due to space and time not being completely objective categories) , however it would be difficult to understand universe without this model. Therefore as long it makes world more intelligible I am inclined to accept causality as the state of affairs. But "purpose" or 'teleos' is a metaphysical term (teleology of beeings, Aristotelian philosphy) is completely alien to physical sciences and I think that mixing them up is an error.

Why is this channel promoting a-biogenesis... the already-disproved idea (by Pasteur) that life, the information systems that make it up, and the specified complexity on which it is based, coming into being by itself, despite all the observable evidence to the contrary?

On top of that, it relies on a fallacy of reification by giving personal attributes to mindless chemical processes/reactions (e.g. being able to "figure out" solutions to problems). Really?...

It also seems to confuse the question. Stating that "in a very real sense, the purpose of life is to continue the mission of the stars" seems as confused as stating that "the purpose of a car engine is to burn its fuel", which merely describes the process that allows it to work, but says nothing about its actual purpose (i.e. to power a vehicle so that it can move around, etc).

It's also difficult, if not impossible, to pose this question and avoid the obvious elephant in the room: the question of whether God does or does not exist. If God exists, then he'd be the purpose-giver, just like we humans gave purpose to the car and its engine. If God does not exist, then everything's just a cosmic fluke and there's no purpose for anything at all (despite our insistence to the contrary) and the only "logical" thing to do would be to be a nihilist.

In a similar way: Saying "entropy is (more or less) the purpose of life" is like dodging the question (and committing a category error): if you argue on the level of entropy (or other basic concepts, like gravity or electromagnetism) the word "purpose" makes no sense. Gravity also has no purpose (on this level). Why should life? It only does "higher up" the ladder - for organisms and - even more literarily - for human beings.

Nobody knows what the purpose of life is. But this video, hinting that it may be something basically physical - is very certainly wrong because this use of "purpose" makes no sense.

I think a big problem with a scientific approach to the question of the "purpose of life" is, that science follows the principles of causality and not finality. For example: Science tells you, that if you jump from a brigde you may die. It doen't tell you if dying is a good or bad thing – or if your purpose is to live or to die. Only if you define "dying = bad" in the first place, then science can tell you if something bad is about to happen if you jump from the bridge. In other words: Science tells you how things in the world are working, it doesn't tell you how they should work. As a consequence the laws of physics only tell you what you can do or not do. They do not tell you what you should do and not do – you cannot break the laws of physics.

I dunno... this seems to be a very life-centered interpretation of entropy, and thus quite circular in attempting to assign meaning.

Entropy would happen with or without life (indeed, it looks quite likely that far more planets have no life than have life in any capacity whatsoever, and there are plenty of non-biotic interactions that do a great job of increasing entropy) so trying to say that the point of life is to increase entropy is like saying that the point of a car is to burn fuel--that's something it does, and even something that we can quantify about the car, but not the reason it exists. The meaning or point of something is the positive value it adds. A car exists toward the purpose of moving people and things around more quickly than walking. On planets where there have never been people or things people care about, cars will generally tend to not exist--even accidentally... On planets where there are people or things people care about (Mars rovers for instance), something to fill that purpose is reasonably likely at a density proportionate to the density of people or things people care about.

The meaning of life, if such a thing isn't an easy to articulate incoherent thought (along the same lines as the concept three-sided rectangles, but harder to recognize absurdity in) has to take a similar form. Hence, we are so bad at figuring out what it might be. We can describe a lot of the mechanics of how life works and how it is fueled, but it's hard to imagine what the destination we are driving toward might be, and all the more so when we can't actually be sure we are making a coherent thought by asking the question of life's meaning in the first place.

I like Aristotle's take on the purpose for human life--to learn and know things, and appreciate beauty. I suspect that the question intrinsically will always evade any proper scientific analysis, so I'm not going to defend it, but that does appear to be the real value that introspection, observation and curiosity add to the beauty of the universe (which I likewise assign as it's purpose without apology or defense, fully acknowledging that the question of the universe's purpose could easily be another incoherent concept).

This video wasn't about the purpose of life at all. It just explains what life does as far as entropy is concerned.
And I really can't blame Sean for this. The problem is simply that asking for the purpose of something that wasn't created makes absolutely no sense at all. It is entirely meaningless.
You might as well ask for the purpose of a mountain, something that came to be through natural processes. You could explain that it sits there and has a passive effect on the weather arround it or that it and everything growing on it form its own ecosystem. But that's just what it does (passively). That isn't a purpose. Something like a hammer, that was indeed created by someone, does have a purpose. Someone made it to drive nails into stuff, among other things.
Once you attribute a purpose to a mountain by saying "the mountain exists to have an influence on the weather" you essentially already assume that it was put there by someone who had a specific idea what this mountain should be doing.
Also, the hammer that was made by someone has a purose, but the materials used to make the hammer do not. No one put that iron into the ground with the intent that some day someone would dig it up to create a hammer with it.
So when you ask for the purpose of life you attribute something to it that only things have that were created. And since life most certainly wasn't created it serves no purpose. It just exists. We just are. Just like a mountain we came to be through blind, natural processes.

The question of "what is the purpose of life" is really only a rather silly one. As sentient animals we are what give things meaning and purpose. Nothing in nature happens with a distinct purpose in mind, things just happen. The big bang happened, there was no reason behind it, it just happened. There was a cause, but that's not the same as a reason. Galaxies, stars, and planets formed from the gasses. There was no reason or purpose for this, it just happened. Life formed, cells divided, multi-cellular lifeforms evolved, and continued to evolve into plants, fish, mammals, and so on. Again, no reason for this. Nothing has a purpose until we give it a purpose with our all too human understanding of the universe.

And so here we are asking "what's the purpose of life?"
Well that's for you to decide.

You seem to confuse a physical phenomena that happens to life with a purpose to it. The confusion here is quite old, Aristotle was probably the first one to come about it, it implies a certain teleology to physical phenomena, "x's purpose is y", this used to be the prominent way biology and even physics was studied until the scientific revolution. The point is, the question of purpose from a scientific point of view is a reversal to ancient Aristotlean metaphysics, it is not an accepted notion within modern science and it shouldn't be, if we are indeed naturalistic or materialists. Given that there is no teleology or "purpose" to a rock or the physical phenomena in the human body, the question becomes more dynamic and perhaps nonsensical.
